item.title: Nurses, Hospitals Prepared For Hurricane Irma To Ensure Patient Care Continues
item.description: September 10, 2017 - Taylor Roberts is a pediatric nurse who is waiting for Hurricane Irma to pass so she can go back to work at Golisano Children's Hospital in Fort Myers, Fla.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 10, 2017 - Taylor Roberts is a pediatric nurse who is waiting for Hurricane Irma to pass so she can go back to work at Golisano Children's Hospital in Fort Myers, Fla. http://www.npr.org/2017/09/10/549989636/nurses-hospitals-prepared-for-hurricane-irma-to-ensure-patient-care-continues

item.title: The Call-In: Conflicting Diet Advice
item.description:
September 10, 2017 - We take listener questions about proper diet. There's been a lot of conflicting advice about what to eat.
- http://www.npr.org/2017/09/10/549865765/the-call-in-conflicting-diet-advice
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 10, 2017 - We take listener questions about proper diet. There's been a lot of conflicting advice about what to eat. http://www.npr.org/2017/09/10/549865765/the-call-in-conflicting-diet-advice

item.title: 'Big Chicken': The Medical Mystery That Traced Back To Slaughterhouse Workers
item.description: September 10, 2017 - In the 1950s, the poultry industry began dunking birds in antibiotic baths. It was supposed to keep meat fresher and healthier. That's not what happened, as Maryn McKenna recounts in her new book.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 10, 2017 - In the 1950s, the poultry industry began dunking birds in antibiotic baths. It was supposed to keep meat fresher and healthier. That's not what happened, as Maryn McKenna recounts in her new book. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/09/10/549586646/big-chicken-the-medical-mystery-that-traced-back-to-slaughterhouse-workers

item.title: Drug For 'Neglected' Chagas Disease Gains FDA Approval Amid Price Worries
item.description: September 10, 2017 - U.S. doctors treating Chagas disease have long wanted FDA approval for a treatment that's widely used in Latin America. But when Martin Shkreli took interest, those doctors panicked — then mobilized.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 10, 2017 - U.S. doctors treating Chagas disease have long wanted FDA approval for a treatment that's widely used in Latin America. But when Martin Shkreli took interest, those doctors panicked — then mobilized. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/09/10/547351794/drug-for-neglected-chagas-disease-gains-fda-approval-amid-price-worries

item.title: Mother Of 9 Goes Door-To-Door As Part Of Yemen's Anti-Cholera Brigade
item.description:
September 9, 2017 - Volunteers are the unsung heroes in slowing the spread of the disease in the world's worst cholera epidemic.
- http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/09/09/547135033/yemen-hasnt-given-up-hope
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: For Teens Knee-Deep In Negativity, Reframing Thoughts Can Help
item.description: September 9, 2017 - Irritation and gloom may seem like the default mode for teenagers, but parents can help them gain a more realistic and resilient way of thinking. A clinical psychologist explains how.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 9, 2017 - Irritation and gloom may seem like the default mode for teenagers, but parents can help them gain a more realistic and resilient way of thinking. A clinical psychologist explains how. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/09/09/549133027/for-teens-knee-deep-in-negativity-reframing-thoughts-can-help

item.title: Using A Robotic Hand, She Wants To Throw Out The First Pitch For All 30 MLB Teams
item.description: September 8, 2017 - At 7, Hailey Dawson loves baseball and tossing out that first pitch. Poland syndrome made it a challenge but a robotic hand made it possible.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 8, 2017 - At 7, Hailey Dawson loves baseball and tossing out that first pitch. Poland syndrome made it a challenge but a robotic hand made it possible. http://www.npr.org/2017/09/08/549460238/using-a-robotic-hand-she-wants-to-throw-out-the-first-pitch-for-all-30-mlb-teams

item.title: Dental Schools Add An Urgent Lesson: Think Twice About Prescribing Opioids
item.description: September 8, 2017 - Opioid painkillers prescribed by dentists have helped fuel the nation's addiction epidemic. Dental schools are teaching the next generation of dentists that there are other ways to treat pain.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 8, 2017 - Opioid painkillers prescribed by dentists have helped fuel the nation's addiction epidemic. Dental schools are teaching the next generation of dentists that there are other ways to treat pain. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/09/08/549218604/dental-schools-add-an-urgent-lesson-think-twice-about-prescribing-opioids

item.title: Local Aid Groups Are Key To Disaster Relief. So Why Are They Overlooked?
item.description: September 8, 2017 - Community-based charities are at the front lines of the flood response in South Asia. But global charities get almost all the attention — and money.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 8, 2017 - Community-based charities are at the front lines of the flood response in South Asia. But global charities get almost all the attention — and money. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/09/08/549246565/south-asias-flood-reveals-frustrating-dynamic-between-aid-groups

item.title: Why Do People Stop Taking Their Meds? Cost Is Just One Reason
item.description: September 8, 2017 - The latest NPR-Truven Health Analytics poll finds that one-third of people say they're stopped taking a prescription drug without telling their doctor. And that could be putting their health at risk.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 8, 2017 - The latest NPR-Truven Health Analytics poll finds that one-third of people say they're stopped taking a prescription drug without telling their doctor. And that could be putting their health at risk. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/09/08/549414152/why-do-people-stop-taking-their-meds-cost-is-just-one-reason

item.title: The Powerful Pull Of Opioids Leaves Many 'Missing' From U.S. Workforce
item.description: September 8, 2017 - Opioid addiction affects people's work lives more than alcohol or other drugs, and those who struggle with it tell strikingly similar tales of deepening alienation from their careers.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 8, 2017 - Opioid addiction affects people's work lives more than alcohol or other drugs, and those who struggle with it tell strikingly similar tales of deepening alienation from their careers. http://www.npr.org/2017/09/08/548867893/the-powerful-pull-of-opioids-leaves-many-missing-from-u-s-workforce

item.title: Governors Sound Off On How To Fix Health Insurance
item.description: September 7, 2017 - Senators holding hearings this week are looking for quick tweaks that will stabilize the insurance markets and make policies cheaper. Some governors want more federal money and more flexibility.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 7, 2017 - Senators holding hearings this week are looking for quick tweaks that will stabilize the insurance markets and make policies cheaper. Some governors want more federal money and more flexibility. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/09/07/549193137/governors-sound-off-on-how-to-fix-health-insurance

item.title: Deadly Bird Flu In China Evolves, Spreads To New Regions
item.description: September 7, 2017 - In the 2017 outbreak, the Chinese government reported 759 cases of the H7N9 avian flu, with 281 deaths. By comparison, in 2016 there were 123 cases.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 7, 2017 - In the 2017 outbreak, the Chinese government reported 759 cases of the H7N9 avian flu, with 281 deaths. By comparison, in 2016 there were 123 cases. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/09/07/549069924/deadly-bird-flu-in-china-evolves-spreads-to-new-regions

item.title: Governors Provide Plans To Fix Health Insurance Markets
item.description: September 7, 2017 - Several governors were in Washington, D.C., to testify before the Senate health committee about their bipartisan plan to shore up the health insurance marketplace. NPR's Robert Siegel talks to Republican Gov. Gary Herbert of Utah and Democratic Gov. John Hickenlooper of Colorado.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 7, 2017 - Several governors were in Washington, D.C., to testify before the Senate health committee about their bipartisan plan to shore up the health insurance marketplace. NPR's Robert Siegel talks to Republican Gov. Gary Herbert of Utah and Democratic Gov. John Hickenlooper of Colorado. http://www.npr.org/2017/09/07/549250049/governors-provide-plans-to-fix-health-insurance-markets

item.title: A Pioneer Of Food Activism Steps Down, Looks Back
item.description: September 7, 2017 - Michael Jacobson invented a new style of food activism. For four decades, he led the fight against "junk food." He's now stepping down as president of the Center for Science in the Public Interest.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 7, 2017 - Michael Jacobson invented a new style of food activism. For four decades, he led the fight against "junk food." He's now stepping down as president of the Center for Science in the Public Interest. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/09/07/548715416/a-pioneer-of-food-activism-steps-down-looks-back
